metadata.title: Bell OH-58 Kiowa
aws::graph::propositions: Advanced Scout Helicopter Program Development
The U.S. Army began evaluating the need to improve the capabilities of their scout aircraft in the 1970s.
The U.S. Army anticipated the AH-64A's replacement of the AH-1.
The AH-1 was a venerable helicopter.
The U.S. Army began shopping the idea of an Aerial Scout Program.
The Aerial Scout Program was intended to stimulate the development of advanced technological capabilities for night vision equipment.
The Aerial Scout Program was intended to stimulate the development of advanced technological capabilities for precision navigation equipment.
The stated goals of the Aerial Scout Program included prototypes with extended target acquisition range capability.
The extended target acquisition range capability would be achieved by means of a long-range stabilized optical subsystem for the observer.
The stated goals of the Aerial Scout Program included prototypes with improved position location.
The improved position location would be achieved through use of a computerized navigation system.
The stated goals of the Aerial Scout Program included prototypes with improved survivability.
The improved survivability would be achieved by reducing aural signatures.
The improved survivability would be achieved by reducing visual signatures.
The improved survivability would be achieved by reducing radar signatures.
The improved survivability would be achieved by reducing infrared signatures.
The stated goals of the Aerial Scout Program included prototypes with improved flight performance capability.
The improved flight performance capability would be derived from a larger engine.
The larger engine would provide compatibility with attack helicopters.
During March 1974, the U.S. Army created a special task force at Fort Knox.
The special task force was created to develop the system requirements.
By 1975, the task force had devised the requirements for an Advanced Scout Helicopter (ASH) program.

text:
### Advanced Scout Helicopter

In the 1970s, the U.S. Army began evaluating the need to improve the capabilities of their scout aircraft. Anticipating the AH-64A's replacement of the venerable AH-1, the Army began shopping the idea of an Aerial Scout Program to stimulate the development of advanced technological capabilities for night vision and precision navigation equipment. The stated goals of the program included prototypes that would: ...possess an extended target acquisition range capability by means of a long-range stabilized optical subsystem for the observer, improved position location through use of a computerized navigation system, improved survivability by reducing aural, visual, radar, and infrared signatures, and an improved flight performance capability derived from a larger engine to provide compatibility with attack helicopters.
During March 1974, the Army created a special task force at Fort Knox to develop the system requirements; by the following year, the task force had devised the requirements for an Advanced Scout Helicopter (ASH) program.
